author: leeederek
content:
hi gm - as Potuz mentioned, speaking on behalf of Offchain Labs (arbitrum+prysm), we definitely do want to see 7907 in Fusaka as many developers and teams on Arbitrum have hit contract size limit hurdles, delaying their mainnet dates, complicating their set up, and could be silently discouraging other teams from attempting to build on the EVM entirely. Happy to share a list of teams if you'd like to see the evidence.

7954 is great alternative but not our first preference by a wide margin. I'm not caught up on the latest discussions relating to the  DoS vectors/risks with 7907 but i would definitely advocate for us to strongly consider keeping 7907

author: potuz
content: for the record Prysm does not have any stake on this discussion though üôÇ

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: I would like to see a block with a 100M transaction that does STATICCALL, EXTCODECOPY, EXTCODESIZE on as many 12KB, 32KB, 48KB contracts as possible <@508125616940515329> is already working on that. Also a STATICCALL chain between 48KB contracts that contain a lot of PUSH1 instructions (for jumpdest analysis)

author: cperezz.eth
content:
EXTCODECOPY isn't worth testing IMO. As you pay for mem expansion. Thus, will always be cheaper and more efficient to perform EXTCODESIZE.

Bonus: If you pop the value from stack and you re-execute it after you have read other contracts, could be possible that the size left the cache, forcing you to load the contract again and counting again.

I have the scenario for EXTCODESIZE in spamoor for 24kB contracts (as is what we have in mainnet and what I have in `anvil`. 

But happy to test against something else if viable.

author: jochembrouwer
content: EXTCODECOPY isn't worth testing IMO. As
